questions.text: Do you often seek out information that supports your existing views?
Do you make an effort to consider viewpoints that differ from your own?
When discussing topics, do you prefer engaging with those who agree with you?
Are you open to changing your opinion when presented with new evidence?

Confirmation Bias.description: A tendency to favor information that confirms your existing beliefs and disregard evidence to the contrary.

questions.text: Do you rely heavily on initial information when making decisions?
Is it easy for you to adjust your opinions when you receive new data?
Are your first impressions of situations usually the most influential?
Do you often revise your estimates after considering additional information?

Anchoring Bias.description: Relying too heavily on the first piece of information encountered when making decisions.

questions.text: Do vivid examples influence your perception of how common something is?
Do you prioritize statistical data over personal anecdotes when evaluating risks?
Are you more swayed by stories you've heard recently than by long-term trends?
Do you consider a wide range of information before forming an opinion?

Availability Heuristic.description: Estimating the likelihood of events based on how easily examples come to mind.

questions.text: Do you often feel that you could have predicted events after they occur?
Do you acknowledge that many outcomes are unpredictable?
Are you surprised by unexpected results?
Do you believe that events are obvious in retrospect?

Hindsight Bias.description: Seeing past events as being more predictable than they were before they took place.

questions.text: Do you trust your judgments even when lacking complete information?
Do you frequently seek input from others when making decisions?
Are you confident in your ability to predict future events?
Do you recognize the limits of your knowledge?

Overconfidence Bias.description: Having excessive confidence in one's own answers or abilities.

questions.text: Do you continue with endeavors because of the time or money already invested?
Is it easy for you to abandon projects that are not yielding results?
Do you feel compelled to follow through on plans due to previous commitments?
Can you change course without worrying about past investments?

Sunk Cost Fallacy.description: Continuing an endeavor due to previously invested resources.

questions.text: Does the way information is presented influence your decisions?
Do you focus on the content rather than the presentation when evaluating information?
Are you more persuaded by positive wording than negative wording?
Do you make decisions based solely on facts, regardless of presentation?

Framing Effect.description: Drawing different conclusions from the same information depending on how it's presented.

questions.text: Do you often adopt opinions because they are popular?
Do you form your opinions independently of others?
Are you influenced by the choices of your peers?
Do you feel comfortable holding views that differ from the majority?

Bandwagon Effect.description: Doing or believing things because many other people do.

questions.text: Do you credit your successes to your abilities and failures to external factors?
Do you take responsibility for mistakes you make?
Are you more likely to blame others when things go wrong?
Do you recognize external factors in your successes?

Self-Serving Bias.description: Attributing positive events to oneself and negative events to external factors.

questions.text: Do you believe people's actions are mainly due to their character?
Do you consider situational factors when evaluating others' behaviors?
Are you quick to judge others without knowing their circumstances?
Do you try to understand the context before forming opinions about others?

Fundamental Attribution Error.description: Overemphasizing personality traits and underemphasizing situational factors when explaining others' behaviors.

questions.text: Do positive impressions in one area influence your overall opinion of someone?
Can you separate different aspects of a person's abilities when evaluating them?
Do you assume someone is good at everything if they excel in one thing?
Do you assess each of a person's qualities independently?

Halo Effect.description: Letting one positive trait influence overall perception of a person or thing.

questions.text: Does a negative trait overshadow your overall impression of someone?
Are you able to recognize positive qualities in someone you dislike?
Do you dismiss people entirely based on a single flaw?
Can you appreciate strengths in others despite their weaknesses?

Horn Effect.description: Allowing one negative trait to overshadow other, more positive traits.

questions.text: Do you prefer the company of people who are similar to you?
Are you equally open to collaborating with anyone, regardless of background?
Do you trust people more if they belong to your own social group?
Do you evaluate others based on individual merits rather than group affiliations?

Ingroup Bias.description: Favoring members of one's own group over those in other groups.

questions.text: Are you more convinced by arguments that align with your beliefs?
Do you assess arguments based on their logic, regardless of the conclusion?
Do you find it hard to accept valid arguments that contradict your views?
Are you open to changing your beliefs when presented with sound reasoning?

Belief Bias.description: Judging arguments based on whether their conclusions align with one's beliefs.

questions.text: Do negative experiences affect you more than positive ones?
Do you give equal attention to both positive and negative feedback?
Are you more likely to remember criticisms over compliments?
Do you focus on successes as much as setbacks?

Negativity Bias.description: Giving more weight to negative experiences over positive ones.

questions.text: Do you believe that a random event is less likely to happen if it has occurred recently?
Do you understand that each random event is independent of previous ones?
Do you expect outcomes to 'even out' in the short term?
Are you aware that patterns in random events are coincidental?

Gambler's Fallacy.description: Believing that future probabilities are altered by past events.

questions.text: Do you prefer to stick with familiar routines over trying new things?
Are you open to making changes when presented with better options?
Do you feel uncomfortable with change, even if it might be beneficial?
Do you actively seek out new experiences?

Status Quo Bias.description: The preference to keep things the same by doing nothing or by sticking with a decision made previously.

questions.text: Do you judge decisions based solely on their outcomes?
Do you consider the decision-making process regardless of the result?
Are you more critical of choices that lead to poor results?
Do you evaluate actions based on the information available at the time?

Outcome Bias.description: Judging a decision based on its outcome rather than on the quality of the decision at the time it was made.

questions.text: Do you believe you are highly skilled in areas where you have little experience?
Do you recognize when you need to learn more about a subject?
Are you confident in your abilities even when you lack expertise?
Do you seek feedback to improve your understanding?

Dunning-Kruger Effect.description: Overestimating one's abilities due to a lack of self-awareness.

questions.text: Do you expect things to turn out well for you?
Are you cautious about potential risks in your plans?
Do you believe negative events are unlikely to happen to you?
Do you consider possible challenges when making decisions?

Optimism Bias.description: Believing that one is less likely to experience negative events.

questions.text: Do you often anticipate negative outcomes?
Are you hopeful about future possibilities?
Do you focus on what might go wrong rather than what could go right?
Do you expect positive results from your efforts?

Pessimism Bias.description: Overestimating the likelihood of negative outcomes.

questions.text: Do you focus on success stories without considering failures?
Do you take into account examples of both success and failure?
Are you influenced mainly by people who have succeeded in a field?
Do you research unsuccessful attempts to gain a balanced perspective?

Survivorship Bias.description: Focusing on the surviving examples and ignoring those that failed.

questions.text: Do you see connections between events that may be unrelated?
Do you require evidence before believing events are linked?
Are you inclined to associate coincidences with meaningful patterns?
Do you recognize when patterns are due to chance?

Illusory Correlation.description: Perceiving a relationship between variables even when no such relationship exists.

questions.text: Do recent events influence your decisions more than past experiences?
Do you consider historical data equally when evaluating situations?
Are your judgments heavily affected by the latest information?
Do you balance recent developments with long-term trends?

Recency Bias.description: Giving greater importance to the most recent event.

questions.text: Do you perceive patterns in random sequences?
Are you aware that random events can appear to have patterns?
Do you believe that streaks in random events are meaningful?
Do you understand that chance events are not influenced by prior outcomes?
Do you accept opinions from authority figures without questioning?
Do you evaluate information critically regardless of the source?
Are you more likely to agree with someone because of their status?
Do you form your own opinions even when they differ from experts?

Authority Bias.description: Placing undue trust in authority figures.

questions.text: Do you believe you are less biased than others?
Are you aware of your own potential biases?
Do you find it easier to spot biases in others than in yourself?
Do you reflect on how your beliefs may be influenced?

Blind Spot Bias.description: Recognizing biases in others but failing to see them in oneself.

questions.text: Do you notice improvements when you believe in the effectiveness of a treatment?
Are you skeptical about results that may be due to expectations?
Does your belief in something enhance its effectiveness for you?
Do you require evidence before attributing improvements to a treatment?

Placebo Effect.description: Experiencing a benefit after a treatment due to expectations.

questions.text: Does knowing who proposed an idea affect your acceptance of it?
Do you evaluate suggestions based on their merits rather than their source?
Are you less receptive to ideas from people you disagree with?
Can you appreciate good ideas regardless of who presents them?

Reactive Devaluation.description: Devaluing proposals because of their source.

questions.text: Do you prefer immediate rewards over larger future benefits?
Are you willing to wait for greater rewards in the future?
Is it difficult for you to delay gratification?
Do you plan for long-term benefits over short-term gains?

Hyperbolic Discounting.description: Preferring smaller, immediate rewards over larger, later rewards.

questions.text: Do you prefer things simply because they are familiar to you?
Are you open to new experiences and options?
Does repeated exposure increase your liking for something?
Do you evaluate things based on their merits rather than familiarity?

Mere Exposure Effect.description: Developing a preference for things merely because they are familiar.

questions.text: Do you assume others share your opinions and beliefs?
Are you aware that others may think differently from you?
Are you surprised when people disagree with your views?
Do you recognize the diversity of perspectives among people?

False Consensus Effect.description: Overestimating how much others agree with us.

questions.text: Do you expect your future preferences to be the same as your current ones?
Do you consider that your tastes and opinions may change over time?
Is it hard for you to imagine your feelings changing in the future?
Do you plan for future changes in your preferences?

Projection Bias.description: Assuming that future preferences will align with current ones.
